learning_outcomes.description: explain a selection of combinatorial topics and their importance;
construct logical, clearly presented and justified solutions to combinatorial problems;
summarise and interpret existing research on related topics and effectively communicate this information in oral and written format.

assessments.task_description: A 10-20-minute seminar-style presentation is to be given in the usual lecture or tutorial timeslots during week 12 or week 13. The presentation will be followed by questions from the audience. Options for seminar content and topics will be given out and discussed in class. A timetable informing students of the date and time for their talk will be given out in class.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Classes

This course has two 2-hour classes per week. Each 2-hour class will be a combination of lecture and students working on problems with help from the lecturer.


Classes will be used to define the course material, set out the basic theory, demonstrate techniques for problem solving, and to provide administrative information for the course. Students are encouraged to answer or ask questions when opportunities arise. There will be opportunity for individual assistance. Students will be given problems to complete during class, giving them the opportunity to work with assistance available from the lecturer, and/or from their peers. The classes also provide an opportunity to ask questions about other aspects of the course.
